name: Kepler-90 - Exosystem With the Most Planets
scenarioDescription:
The KOI-351 Exoplanetary System

KOI-351 is a star with 1.2 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.2 times its radius. It is located 2544.02 light years away from the solar system.

KOI-351 is known to have 8 exoplanets in orbit around it.

KOI-351 b

KOI-351 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-01. Its semi-major axis is 0.07 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 7.01 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, KOI-351.

The mass of KOI-351 b is 1.84 times the mass of Earth. The radius of KOI-351 b is 1.31 that of Earth. At 1.84 Earth masses, KOI-351 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

KOI-351 c

KOI-351 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-01. Its semi-major axis is 0.09 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 8.72 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, KOI-351.

The mass of KOI-351 c is 1.46 times the mass of Earth. The radius of KOI-351 c is 1.19 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, KOI-351 c is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.

KOI-351 d

KOI-351 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-01. Its semi-major axis is 0.32 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 59.74 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, KOI-351.

The mass of KOI-351 d is 12.08 times the mass of Earth. The radius of KOI-351 d is 2.87 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, KOI-351 d is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.

KOI-351 e

KOI-351 e was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-01. Its semi-major axis is 0.42 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 91.94 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, KOI-351.

The mass of KOI-351 e is 10.04 times the mass of Earth. The radius of KOI-351 e is 2.66 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, KOI-351 e is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.

KOI-351 f

KOI-351 f was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-01. Its semi-major axis is 0.48 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 124.91 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, KOI-351.

The mass of KOI-351 f is 12.19 times the mass of Earth. The radius of KOI-351 f is 2.88 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, KOI-351 f is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.

KOI-351 g

KOI-351 g was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-01. Its semi-major axis is 0.71 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 210.61 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, KOI-351.

The mass of KOI-351 g is 145.92 times the mass of Earth. The radius of KOI-351 g is 8.1 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, KOI-351 g is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.

KOI-351 h

KOI-351 h was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-01. Its semi-major axis is 1.01 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 331.60 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, KOI-351.

The mass of KOI-351 h is 323.95 times the mass of Earth. The radius of KOI-351 h is 11.3 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, KOI-351 h is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system KOI-351, which contains 8 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
